awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Hybrid-Compatible Deformation Processing of Performance Critical Components
awd_abstract_narration:
Additive manufacturing has emerged as a viable route for fabricating complex machine components that have important applications in the aerospace, defense, automotive and energy sectors. Unfortunately, machine components made through additive manufacturing are often unreliable due to internal defects. This prohibits their industrial use as defective components can respond to normal service conditions in unexpected ways or fail prematurely. This award supports research to establish a novel hybrid-additive method for fabrication of defect-free components, and therefore directly impacts economic welfare and national security. This hybrid approach will repair defects using local severe deformation. Modeling efforts that will support this research will enable rapid fabrication of high quality additively manufactured components. The project will also support several classroom teaching initiatives including those focused at the K-12, undergraduate and graduate levels. These include (i) incorporation of research results into an interactive educational computer game and (ii) dissemination through short video-scribe movies available for viewing in open social media platforms.
 
The goal of this project is to facilitate defect control in additively manufactured components through hybrid post-processing methods. For achieving this goal, the methodology will involve systematic use of plastic deformation in interwoven steps during additive manufacturing for mitigation of volumetric defects. Modeling efforts will involve detailed characterization of material microstructure evolution under graded plastic strain. Microstructure parameters of interest include grain structure and defect structure. The deformation response of these parameters will be studied using in situ loading platforms that will work with existing electron microscopes and X-Ray computed tomography machines. Deformation strain fields will be characterized using digital image correlation through secondary electron imaging. These strain fields will be correlated with the evolving micro-structure parameters that will be characterized simultaneously. A process modeling framework for prediction of the surface microstructure as a function of processing conditions will be validated and used to determine optimal hybrid strategies for post processing additively manufactured microstructures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp

por.por_cntn:
Additive manufacturing processes can be used to fabricate modern high-performance parts. The complex geometries of such parts preclude other traditional manufacturing approaches as routes for their efficient production. However, the physics underlying additive manufacturing processes naturally encourages the formation of defects and this phenomenon is challenging to control or monitor precisely. Hence, parts resulting from additive manufacturing must undergo post-processing to ensure that their performance is not compromised by undetected defects that were produced during fabrication. The scientific achievements that resulted from this proposal will enable the optimization of such post-processes to ensure fidelity, and longevity of performance-critical parts that are produced using additive manufacturing. 

 

The research performed as part of this proposal focused on understanding the mechanics of surface post-processing of parts resulting from additive manufacturing. For this objective, experiments were designed to understand: (i) the fundamental mechanics of materials during surface post-processing, (ii) how the presence of defects affect this mechanics, and (iii) how this knowledge can be used to systematically optimize surface post-processes of complex parts. To understand the fundamental mechanics of materials relevant to surface post-processes, controlled environments were designed and implemented using a custom mechanical deformation stage that was built as part of this project. The behavior of the materials during deformation imposed on this stage was characterized by in-situ optical strain mapping, and post-mortem characterization by electron microscopy. Insights obtained from these experiments were utilized to rationalize how the presence of defects that may result from additive manufacturing influence material behavior during surface post processes. This was accomplished by controlled computational investigations that were also formulated and implemented as part of the project. 

 

These investigations produced calibrated analytical and numerical models that can be utilized to evaluate how uncontrolled defects can affect the ability of parts resulting from additive manufacturing to be post-processed. These models can be used in the design of advanced performance-critical parts, to advise geometry features that can facilitate optimization of post-processes. This ability can enable the rapid deployment of parts that are designed to be fabricated by additive manufacturing, which is currently not possible. This is an important contribution of the work performed as part of this proposal because it enables the integration of upstream, viz., design, and downstream, viz. post-processing, phased of advanced part-production. 

 

The research experience for teachers supplement that was acquired as part of this project was utilized to set up an advanced manufacturing lab in a grammar school in VA. This lab is routinely utilized by the instructors there to demonstrated concepts in advanced manufacturing to young students. Such demonstrations are expected to facilitate clarity of understanding of advanced manufacturing concepts at the grammar school level, and thereby garner general interest in STEM. The project also supported the development of modules on advanced manufacturing for an undergraduate course, and the training of several undergraduate and graduate students who were directly involved with the project. 


Last Modified: 01/02/2024
Modified by: Saurabh Basu
